parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or any other clear identifier.  It promotes a website that helps voters find compatible parties, but doesn't endorse any particular candidate.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message is clearly intended to reach a wide audience of Romanian voters. The use of a website link further supports this.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. While the post relates to the parliamentary elections by offering a tool to help voters choose, its primary objective is not to directly influence the vote for a specific candidate or party. The aim seems to be to encourage informed voting through the use of a compatibility test, rather than promoting a particular candidate.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>True. The post could be considered a form of citizen journalism or public service announcement, aiming to educate voters and facilitate their participation in the electoral process. It provides information and a tool to help voters make informed decisions, without explicitly advocating for any particular candidate or party.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Not applicable. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; instead, it presents a service aimed at helping voters.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1101485344697801</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, while related to the parliamentary elections, does not constitute electoral propaganda under Article 98 t) of LEGE nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015.  The post promotes a website designed to help voters find politically compatible parties, which is an act of civic engagement and voter education, not an attempt to sway votes for a specific candidate.  The post does not advocate for or against any particular candidate or party.  The absence of any direct endorsement or negative campaigning distinguishes it from prohibited electoral propaganda.  The fact that it is a paid advertisement does not automatically make it electoral propaganda; the content itself must be analyzed.  In this case, the content promotes informed voting, which is a positive contribution to the democratic process.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>DifinePR</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
